repository.corpname: Archives & Special Collections at the Thomas J. Dodd Research Center, University of Connecticut Library

did.unittitle: Alfred E. Moss Collection
did.abstract: Mr. Albert E. Moss was a faculty member at Connecticut Agricultural College (now the University of Connecticut) for twenty-nine years. He is best known for his work in the field of Forestry. Focus of the collection is survey work on the transfer of land to and from the University of Connecticut.

bioghist.head: Biography
bioghist.p: Albert E. Moss began his career at Connecticut Agricultural College as an instructor of Forestry in 1914. He became an assistant Professor of Forestry between 1914 and 1927. He eventually rose to the position of full professor of Forestry in 1928 and would hold that position until his retirement in 1943. He is known for his extensive field work on virgin forest tree identification and plantings, documenting logging practices and the rising number of sawmills in the United States, stream and dam improvements, and the restocking of rivers with native fish. He worked in conjunction with the Department of Forestry and Wildlife Management to document government timber sales. Although his main focus was on New England forests, primarily Connecticut lands, his fieldwork took him as far as California. He is known at the University of Connecticut for his surveys and mapping of University land.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: This collection contains the professional work of Albert E. Moss. Included are his extensive field notes, films, and slides pertaining to his work in the field of forestry. The collection also includes the surveys and deeds of lands surrounding the University of Connecticut [Storrs] campus, and the transfers of ownership of the lands dating back to the mid-eighteenth century up to and including the mid-twentieth century. The collection does not include any information pertaining to his personal life. A significant portion of the survey work appears to have been conducted by Thomas B. Danielson>.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series I: University of Connecticut Land Survey (1761-1958) Surveyors notes on University property lines and deed notes on lands bought and sold.

Series II: Field Notes (1911-1976) Moss and Danielson field notes on University land topography including water commission, sewer level surveys, river and land visibility studies, and survey notes on deeded lands.

Series III: Land Deeds, Leases, Maps and Surveys (1773-1976) Official deeds and unofficial deed notes on properties conveyed to and from the University and property owners, including surveys of properties deeded. Maps of properties bought and sold, town lines, and Connecticut Light and Power surveys of University substations.
Series IV: Visual materials (1920-1965) This portion of the collection has been inventoried but not processed. Includes films, plate negatives and photos of Forestry work done in the United States.

userestrict.head: Restrictions on Use
userestrict.p: Permission to publish from these Papers must be obtained in writing from the owner(s) of the copyright.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Item description, #:#], Albert E. Moss Collection. Archives & Special Collections at the Thomas J. Dodd Research Center, University of Connecticut Library.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: The collection was donated by Dr. Walter Wardell in March 1994.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: The materials listed in Series IV have been inventoried but not completely processed. Please contact the Curator for Multimedia Collection for specifics.

accessrestrict.head: Access
accessrestrict.p: The collection is open and available for research.

altformavail.head: Location of Copies or Alternate Formats
altformavail.p: Digital reproductions of materials in this collection may also be found in the Archives & Special Collections digital repository.

accessrestrict.head: Access
accessrestrict.p: Original photographic negatives are not available for use due to their fragility. Original photographic prints in Series V, subseries C were made from the negatives.

did.unittitle: Subseries A: Film

accessrestrict.head: Access
accessrestrict.p: Originals not available due to fragility. Use reference copies.

did.unittitle: Swamp logging, Longleaf Pine, Southern United States
did.physdesc: 1 film reel (9 min., 37 sec.): si., col.; 16 mm.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Film depicts the logging of virgin forests of Longleaf Pines throughout the Southeast United States. The exact site is most likely North Carolina or Florida. The Longleaf Pine was valued for lumber and for its resin, which was used in navy stores, and the production of turpentine and rosin. By the time of this film the Longleaf Pine had been almost entirely cleared from North America and replaced with faster growing varieties of pine. The footage includes examples of the use of a steam donkey, or steam driven winch, a geared steam locamotive, a steam skidder, and a variety of hand tools. At 7 min. 33. a man is seen stripping bark off of pines to harvest resin. The camera focuses on two different views of his bark stripping tool. Researchers interested in this video will find slides from the same trip in Subseries B: Lantern Slides of the Alfred E. Moss Collection. Moss screened the film at a meeting of the Storrs Movie Makers Club. More on the club can be found in the Jerauld A. Manter Collection (MSS1991.0032). Total run time 9 min. 40 sec.

did.unittitle: Forestry, Connecticut hardwood, logging, sawmill
did.physdesc: 1 film reel (9 min., 12 sec.): si., b&w; 16 mm.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Film depicts hardwood logging in Connecticut. Several students can be seen in the beginning of the footage measuring tree sizes and taking notes. Trees can be seen being loaded on to a horse-drawn sled. At 12 min. 20 sec. and 13 min. 55 sec. a sawmill is documented. At 18 min. the video cuts to the transplanting of seedlings in a garden plot. Total run time 10 min. 23 sec.

did.unittitle: Logging, Maine
did.physdesc: 1 film reel (18 min., 31 sec.): si., b&w and col.; 16 mm.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: University of Connecticut students in the former town of Davidson, Maine at the location of the Summit Lumber Company. Film documents students involved in surveying, logging, recreation activities and life in camp. Total run time 18 min. 28 sec.

did.unittitle: Chopping contest
did.physdesc: 1 film reel (4 min.): si., b&w; 16 mm.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Film documents a wood chopping contest hosted by the Hartford Farm Bureau. The winner recieves a cash prize and runner up participants are awarded new axe heads. Total run time 3 min. 3 sec.

did.unittitle: Chopping contest, Connecticut Agricultural College
did.physdesc: 1 film reel (3 min., 31 sec); si., b&w; 16 mm.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Film documents a controlled burn demonstration and then cuts to a wood chopping competition in front of the Hawley Armory Building at the Connecticut Agricultural College. Film was likely taken the same day as MSS1990.0031/MP4. Film ends with several seconds of men chopping trees in a river. Total run time 3 min. 8 sec.

did.unittitle: Felling Trees with jack
did.physdesc: 1 film reel (7 min., 2 sec.): si., col.; 16 mm.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Film documents a method for felling trees. A direction cut is made and then a portion of the felling cut. The demonstrator then cuts a notch into the opposite side of the directional cut, inserts a jack and fells the tree using the jack. Film may have been made for classroom or Extension Service work. Total run time 7 min. 5 sec.

did.unittitle: Water wheel detail
did.physdesc: 1 film reel (1 min., 42 sec.): si., b&w; 16 mm.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Close up of a water wheel. Moss was a member of the Storrs Movie Makers Club and the film may have been shot for that. More on the club can be found in the Jerauld A. Manter Collection (MSS1991.0032)Total run time 1 min. 34 sec.

did.unittitle: Tree Planting Instructional
did.physdesc: 1 film reel (10 min., 2 sec.): si., b&w: 16 mm.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Film provides instructions for the planting of conifer seedlings. Two steps are covered, planting seedlings as bunch to allow them to root, and then seperating and planting individual seedlings. Camera pans over tools needed at start. Total run time 10 min. 30 sec.

did.unittitle: Org Fallout Films, SOF Fallout in Food
did.physdesc: 1 film reel (25 min., 7 sec.): sd., b&w; 16 mm.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Fallout in Food was produced for This Is UConn by the College of Agriculture. Film was directed at housewives and interviews University faculty and experts in the field about the risks of nucear fallout, particularly that of Strontium 90, contamination in meat, milk, prepackaged and canned foods, fruits, and vegetables. UConn faculty include; Donald Kinsman of the Department of Animal Husbandry, Joe McNeil, a food scientist, and Fred Ellers of the Department of Plant Sciences. Emphasis is on the relative safety of milk products and how to de-contanimate food in the event of nuclear fallout, or radioactive dust. Film mentions government testing facilities in Oakridge, TN. The program "This is UConn" was shown on Channel 8, Connecticut Public Television. More on radiation testing at UConn can be found in the University of Connecticut, President's Office Records, Homer D. Babbidge Collection (MSS1998.0183) and more on the College of Agriculture's response to public fears about nuclear fallout can be found in the College of Agriculture collection (MSS1997.0010). Total run time 25 min. 15 sec.

did.unittitle: Subseries B: Lantern slides
Forestry activities and 4-H, New England

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Includes trips to Cathedral Pines, Cornwall; White Plantation, Eagleville; Shaker Pines, Enfield; Cushman Farm, North Grandby; R. & W. Pine Plantation, Maine; Goodwin Forest; Shaker Pines, Hazardville; 4-H forestry activities documented include trail construction, C.S.C. trails, fire and cattle damage to forests, Christmas tree planting, planting and timber estimating. Original container for lantern slides labeled "Extension Service, Storrs, Connecticut."

did.unittitle: Forestry and logging, Northeastern Connecticut

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Includes forestry camp in Union, Connecticut; fire plots in Gurleyville; forests in Mansfield Depot; thinning of the Pine Acres Farm, Hampton, Connecticut.
